author: By Jonathan Abrams and Christopher Kuo
title: Norman Lear Reshaped How America Saw Black Families
description: “Good Times,” “The Jeffersons” and “Sanford and Son” brought a wave of Black characters to TV, even as the shows opened up tensions over stereotypes.
content: As a birthday present for Tyler Perry last year, a mutual acquaintance arranged for him to meet one of his heroes, Norman Lear. Perry grew up watching Lear’s groundbreaking television shows, and was awed by how several presented a fuller version of Black lives onto American television screens for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 24 Things That Stuck With Us in 2023
description: Films, TV shows, albums, books, art and A.I.-generated SpongeBob performances that reporters, editors and visual journalists in Culture couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
content: At the Frick, where Barkley Hendricks’s shimmering ’70s portraits are hanging, posthumously, in the museum’s first solo show by a Black artist, I kept thinking about that Langston Hughes poem: What does happen to a dream deferred? Hendricks didn’t live to see his subjects, with their plentiful Afros and bell-bottom cool, leaping, communing, strolling across the walls of an institution he frequented. But after quietly railing at the omission, I realized the exhibition is actually about Hendricks taking his rightful place — a kind of insistence that a dream, rather than fossilizing, can go on forever. REBECCA THOMAS
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: We Can’t Stop Writing Paper Checks. Thieves Love That.
description: Although check usage has declined in the last couple of decades, check fraud has risen sharply, creating a problem for banks — and customers trying to pay their bills.
content: When Pam Berns mailed a few checks to pay bills, she had no idea such a routine task would throw her small publishing business into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: It’s a Game Show!
description: True stories told in the form of a game show.
content: Something “This American Life” had never done before: true stories told in the form of a game show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These Ryan O’Neal Movies
description: The actor became one of the most bankable stars in Hollywood, and proved himself equally adept at drama, comedy and action.
content: Ryan O’Neal’s death Friday at the age of 82 followed decades in which the actor was better known for his personal life (and struggles) than for his work. But few stars shone brighter in the 1970s, when O’Neal — originally known for his role on the prime-time soap opera “Peyton Place” — became one of the most bankable stars in Hollywood, and proved himself equally adept at drama, comedy and action. Here are a few of his finest films from that period, and where to stream them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Emily Garthwaite
title: Why Fears of a Broader Middle East Conflict Are Growing in Iraq
description: Iran-backed forces are assembling drones and retrofitting rockets in the territory of an American ally. They are used in attacks on U.S. outposts in Iraq and Syria.
content: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River. But few risk spending much time there. Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Julie Creswell
title: Shoppers, Facing Holiday Spending, Turn to Loyalty Programs
description: The programs and the incentives that come with them will be critical for retailers hoping to attract cash-strapped customers over the next month.
content: Chrissy West is taking a new approach to her Christmas shopping this year. When buying gifts for her family, she plans to finance them by cashing in her Ulta loyalty points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and John Taggart
title: The Holiday Boom in New York Is Back. Sort Of.
description: After three years of less foot traffic and less spending, things are looking up this year, even if it’s not 2019 again.
content: People have long traveled from all over the world to experience the glitz and bustle of New York City during the holidays. But for three years, that influx of visitors — and their open wallets — has been diminished, thanks to the impact of Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: What to Know About Elizabeth Magill, the Penn President Who Resigned
description: Ms. Magill, who had been in her post since last year, stepped down four days after testifying before Congress.
content: The president of the University of Pennsylvania, Elizabeth Magill, resigned on Saturday, four days after she came under fire for her responses at a congressional hearing on Tuesday in which she was pressed, along with the presidents of Harvard and M.I.T., on whether students calling for the genocide of Jews should be disciplined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Bowers
title: Artificial Intelligence Is an Unreliable Narrator
description: Approaching A.I. like we might any other art form — with a dose of skepticism and an eye toward what inspired it — might make its creations feel less threatening.
content: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 9, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 9, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about accusations of sexual violence during the Hamas Oct. 7 attacks on Israel misstated the kind of evidence Israeli authorities have gathered in their investigation. The police are relying mainly on witness testimony, not on autopsies or forensic evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Key Players in OpenAI’s Boardroom Drama
description: A mix of prominent tech industry figures and people not well known outside the A.I. community played big roles in the upheaval at the company.
content: On Nov. 17, Silicon Valley tumbled into turmoil when Sam Altman, chief executive of the high-profile A.I. start-up OpenAI, was suddenly removed by the company’s board of directors. After a five-day roller-coaster ride that encapsulated the increasingly heated battle over the future of artificial intelligence, Mr. Altman was reinstated and a new board was created. Here is a list of players in the year’s biggest tech drama:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Adams’s Swagger Is Diminished. His Foes Are Ready to Pounce
description: Eric Adams is facing stronger pushback from the City Council and progressives, and prominent Democrats in New York are considering running for mayor.
content: If Mayor Eric Adams were in search of evidence that his recent spate of troubles had cost him some standing in New York, he would not need to look far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Talk of a Trump Dictatorship Charges the American Political Debate
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and his allies are not doing much to reassure those worried about his autocratic instincts. If anything, they seem to be leaning into the predictions.
content: When a historian wrote an essay the other day warning that the election of former President Donald J. Trump next year could lead to dictatorship, one of Mr. Trump’s allies quickly responded by calling for the historian to be sent to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: A String of Lawsuits Takes Aim at Regulators
description: The attacks, once unthinkable, could upend how a suite of agencies including the F.T.C. and the S.E.C. enforce rules.
content: When Meta sued the Federal Trade Commission last week — the social networking giant’s latest effort to block new restrictions on its monetization of user data — it used an increasingly common argument against government regulators: The complaint alleged that the structure of the F.T.C. was unconstitutional and that its in-house trials were invalid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Minnesota Is Looking for a New State Flag. Residents Have a Few (Thousand) Ideas.
description: A commission is weighing 6 finalists, and a new state flag could be flying in Minnesota by sometime next year.
content: Ask Minnesotans about the state’s official flag, and prepare for a crush of critiques.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: State Department Bypasses Congress to Approve Israel’s Order for Tank Ammunition
description: It is the first time the Biden administration has declared an emergency to expedite arms shipments to the Middle East, which are controversial because of the civilian death toll from Israeli airstrikes.
content: The State Department is pushing through a government sale to Israel of 13,000 rounds of tank ammunition, bypassing a congressional review process that is generally required for arms sales to foreign nations, according to a State Department official and an online post by the Defense Department on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Biden Should Make an Immigration Deal With Republicans
description: The border is a big part of the president’s re-election problem.
content: Over the last few months, the incredulous question — How can Donald Trump possibly be leading the polls; there must be some mistake — has given way to the clear reality: Something in American life would need to change for Joe Biden to be favored for re-election in November 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Neil Gaiman’s Son Thinks His Dad Is in Charge of ‘Doctor Who’
description: “It’s fun doing something that’s a bit terrifying sometimes,” says the “Sandman” writer, who will reprise his beloved reading of “A Christmas Carol” at Town Hall.
content: When the “Sandman” author Neil Gaiman was approached in 2013 about reading “A Christmas Carol” at the New York Public Library, his requirements were simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The A.C.L.U. Has a New Client: The National Rifle Association
description: The civil liberties group says it opposes the N.R.A. and its mission but has agreed to represent it in the Supreme Court in a free-speech case.
content: The American Civil Liberties Union and the National Rifle Association agree about very little. They are often on opposite sides in major cases, and they certainly have starkly different views about gun rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: 7 Deaths Linked to Small Magnets Found in Toys, U.S. Warns
description: A federal agency said the deaths and more than 2,000 emergency-room visits have been tied to pea-size magnets that are easily ingested.
content: A federal safety agency warned this week that small, powerful magnets have been linked to seven deaths after they were ingested, announcing one company’s voluntary recall of a toy set that contained such magnets and issuing warnings about six other companies with similar toys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Israel strikes targets across the Gaza Strip.
description: The Israeli military struck targets from the air, ground and sea across the Gaza Strip overnight into Saturday, it said, as air-raid sirens warning of incoming rocket fire blared in Israeli communities near Gaza.
content: The Israeli military struck targets from the air, ground and sea across the Gaza Strip overnight into Saturday, it said, as air-raid sirens warning of incoming rocket fire blared in Israeli communities near Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Stuffy, Preppy, Sleepy: Can a Rebrand Fix Connecticut’s Reputation?
description: The state has retired its “Still Revolutionary” slogan in favor of twin marketing campaigns: “Make It Here” and “Find Your Vibe.”
content: What comes to mind when you think of Connecticut?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk Says He May Bring Conspiracy Theorist Alex Jones Back to X
description: Jones was banned from the social media platform in 2018 after posting harassing messages.
content: Elon Musk said on Saturday that he would consider allowing the right-wing provocateur and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones to return to X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter. Mr. Jones was banned from Twitter in 2018 after posting harassing messages, a month after other tech companies like Facebook and YouTube also suspended his accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Abdi Latif Dahir, Alex Travelli and Clifford Krauss
title: Tiny Electric Vehicles Pack a Bigger Climate Punch Than Cars
description: Two- and three-wheeled vehicles, used by billions of people, are moving away from fossil fuels to batteries faster than cars in countries that have made the energy transition a priority.
content: Big Oil faces a tiny foe on the streets of Asia and Africa. The noisy, noxious vehicles that run on two and three wheels, carrying billions of people daily, are quietly going electric — in turn knocking down oil demand by one million barrels a day this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Waltzing Matilda
description: A farewell, of sorts.
content: I started working for the Times’s Australia bureau in 2020, writing stories from my kitchen table — my makeshift office in a locked-down Melbourne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Inside the Parties of Art Basel Miami Beach
description: Harmony Korine made his D.J. debut, Janelle Monáe held a private concert and Gagosian hosted a poolside event.
content: Miami Art Week is in full swing in South Florida, anchored by Art Basel Miami Beach. We were on the scene for parties in the area that featured the performer Janelle Monáe, the filmmaker Harmony Korine and prominent figures from the art world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What’s on Your Best-of List for 2023? We Want to Know.
description: Best line from a movie? Best pasta recipe? Best advice? Tell us your highly subjective, super-specific favorites from the past year.
content: What’s on your own best-of list for 2023? Think about everything you consumed, regardless of genre: yes, the best thing you watched, but also the best thing you ate, the best advice you received, the best app you discovered, the best line you encountered in a movie, the best book you read that’s been sitting on your shelf for over a decade, the best change you made to your evening routine. (For inspiration, check out reader favorites from last year.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack and Samar Hazboun
title: For Palestinians, the Future Is Being Bulldozed
description: The West Bank is policed by armed settlers and littered with destroyed houses that residents are forbidden to repair.
content: The men came alone that morning, leaving families and sheep behind, and climbed the hill to see what was left of their village. On the sun-bleached crest, they found a scene of wreckage: The windows of the makeshift clinic had been smashed, household furniture lay shattered; sections of the schoolhouse had been burned to ash. There were drifts of clothing and stray shoes spread on the ground throughout the abandoned village, small things dropped in haste when the families fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Ryan O’Neal, Master of the Offbeat Meet-Cute
description: The former boxer had a gift for mixing innocence and wit. It didn’t hurt that he had the face of a good guy.
content: He had the face of a fairy-tale lead, the kind that would have fit agreeably in an earlier Hollywood era but felt comfortingly alluring in the moment. Ryan O’Neal was a boxer in his youth — announcing his father had died on Friday, his son Patrick O’Neal pointed fans toward YouTube footage of O’Neal fighting Joe Frazier on national TV, with Muhammad Ali doing commentary. But when he migrated to acting, it suited him, and by 1964 he had become a star thanks to the ABC prime-time soap opera “Peyton Place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Cartel Tried to Extort a Town, but the Town Fought Back, Officials Say
description: At least 14 people were killed in a clash between the gunmen and members of a small farming community in central Mexico, an episode that the state authorities cast as a gang extortion attempt that backfired.
content: A​ clash between gunmen and members of a small farming community in central Mexico has left at least 14 people dead, the state authorities said Saturday, casting the violence as a gang extortion attempt that backfired when residents fought back.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: First Gene-Editing Treatment is Approved for Use in People
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 9, 2023.
content: “It is practically a miracle that this is even possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Win a Reporting Trip With Me
description: Every year I take a student along with me on a reporting trip to generate interest in neglected stories.
content: I’m delighted to invite university students to apply for my 2024 win-a-trip contest. I’ve been holding these contests since 2006, and taking the winners along with me on a reporting trip to cover global poverty and social justice issues. My aim is to get more people writing about these neglected topics and to generate more interest in them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Why Haven’t More Older Adults Gotten the R.S.V. Vaccine?
description: The virus sends up to 160,000 people over 65 to hospitals every year. But just 15 percent have gotten the newly available shots.
content: Toby Gould was an early adopter. In September, Mr. Gould, 78, went to a pharmacy in Hyannis, Mass., to get one of the new vaccines for respiratory syncytial virus, known as R.S.V. He has asthma, which would heighten his risk of serious illness if he were to be infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Old New Way to Provide Cheap Housing
description: Twenty-first-century versions of rooming houses are cropping up and housing workers with few other options.
content: Homelessness is an American tragedy, but it’s not hopeless. In a recent column, I explored how Houston has become a national model by reducing homelessness by more than 60 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle, Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Karen Weise
title: Inside OpenAI’s Crisis Over the Future of Artificial Intelligence
description: Split over the leadership of Sam Altman, board members and executives turned on one another. Their brawl exposed the cracks at the heart of the A.I. movement.
content: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas. He was in the city for its inaugural Formula 1 race, which had drawn 315,000 visitors including Rihanna and Kylie Minogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: SmileDirectClub Shuts Down After Filing for Bankruptcy
description: The telehealth company, which sold teeth alignment devices to two million customers, was unprofitable and had been criticized by medical groups.
content: SmileDirectClub, a telehealth company that sold teeth-straightening devices through the mail and faced criticism from medical groups, said on Friday that it had shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Our Schools Can Do to Reverse Learning Loss
description: Readers discuss an editorial about how to address declining test scores and chronic absenteeism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: While Gazans Suffer, Hamas Reaps the Benefits
description: It has gained prestige among Palestinians while poisoning Israel’s relations with the Arab world and putting the Palestinian issue back on the Western agenda.
content: Much of Gaza lies in ruins, with its people pushed from their homes by Israeli bombardment and the death toll climbing ever higher. On the ground, Hamas, which has ruled Gaza for 16 years, has largely vanished, other than when its fighters pop up to attack Israeli tanks or fire rockets at Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Mideast War Pushes Companies to Extend Diversity Programs to Faith Groups
description: Workers are asking employers to respond to rising Islamophobia and antisemitism. But office discussions about religion are complicated.
content: When Nabeela Elsayed was speaking at a corporate conference several years ago and explained that she would miss the group dinner because she was fasting for Ramadan, she recalls, her manager responded: “Just don’t fast.” Ms. Elsayed, an executive coach who was previously chief operating officer for Walmart Canada, said she had heard many such slights when stepping away during the workday to pray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Pillar of the Superhero Community
description: Looking for a convivial themeless puzzle? Here come Doug Peterson and Christina Iverson to save the day.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Look, we all know it’s Saturday and you’re going have to wrestle with the crossword for a while, but this is definitely a grid you’ll wind up shaking hands with at the end and maybe even taking out for lunch. It’s affable. It’s the first Times collaboration between two constructing veterans, Christina Iverson (now a puzzle editor here) and Doug Peterson (who has made 55 prior puzzles for us).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: The Pickleball Courts Outside Our Townhouse Are TOO LOUD!
description: The increasingly unavoidable sport is causing disputes among players and court neighbors around the country.
content: Q: We live in a gated townhouse community in Essex County, N.J. When we purchased our unit two years ago, there were tennis courts behind our deck, which never caused a problem. But now the two courts closest to us have been converted to pickleball courts, and the noise from the balls and the players is loud, disturbing our quality of life. Play starts at 7:30 a.m. on some days. We can’t use our deck, and our bedroom faces the courts, so we can’t sleep with the windows open. The overhead lights are on until 8:30 p.m., shining into the back of our house. We have asked the property owner’s association to move the courts farther away and to put up soundproofing, but we’ve been ignored. What action can we take?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What (and Why) Will We Buy in 2024?
description: We asked a global group of entrepreneurs, business leaders and academics to assess consumer behavior and what it could mean for the coming year and beyond.
content: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Roberts-Grmela and Claire Fahy
title: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Targeting Wall St. Denounce U.S. Veto of U.N. Cease-Fire Resolution
description: The demonstration, called “Shut Down Wall Street” and meant to urge an end to the United States’ financial support of Israel, became a forum to express anger over the U.S. veto.
content: Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters took to the streets of Lower Manhattan on Friday afternoon for what was billed as a “Shut Down Wall Street” event, just as the United States vetoed a resolution at the United Nations Security Council calling for a permanent cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Stolen Checks Are for Sale Online. We Called Some of the Victims.
description: One reason this fraud is rampant: Open forums where anyone can buy checks that thieves have taken from the mail.
content: Our national check-writing habit is turning into an enormous problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Ivy League Flunks Out
description: We shouldn’t need to tell these smart people how ignorant they sound.
content: This column was updated to reflect the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: In Soldiers’ Remains, Russia Plots a Way to Reconcile With France
description: A man with close ties to the Kremlin went looking for and found the remains of World War I Russian soldiers in France. Moscow hopes to use the discovery for diplomatic purposes.
content: On a recent cloudy afternoon, the remains of three Russian soldiers were buried in virtual secrecy in a small corner of northeastern France. There were no Russian officials at the funeral. No Russian flag was hoisted. No Russian anthem was played.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Israeli Strikes Pound Gaza a Day after U.S. Vetoes Cease-Fire Resolution.
description: Some of the strikes targeted the southern Gaza Strip, where the Israeli military has ordered civilians to go to avoid bombardment.
content: Israel unleashed a barrage of airstrikes across Gaza on Saturday, killing dozens of people and sending hundreds of wounded to overwhelmed hospitals, according to health authorities in the territory. The attacks came a day after the United States vetoed a U.N. Security Council resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Kids Look White. Does My Thai Father Make Them Asian?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on representing multiracial heritage, especially when the details are complex.
content: I am a 48-year-old biracial daughter of a Thai immigrant and a white woman who divorced when I was 5. My father moved back to Thailand after the separation, and I didn’t see him again for 26 years. After the divorce, my maternal family was eager to erase my Southeast Asian heritage. I was baptized in my grandparents’ church, and my Muslim surname was legally changed to my mother’s family name. Although I greatly resemble my father, we did not acknowledge him in any way. I have since forgotten many of the Thai customs I grew up with before my parents’ divorce. Culturally speaking, I am a Midwestern-born Colorado resident with little to show for my Thai heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Matt Surman
title: The Palestinian Authority’s leader assails the U.S. veto of a U.N. cease-fire resolution.
description: Criticism of a U.S. veto of a United Nations Security Council resolution for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza grew on Saturday, with rights groups and aid organizations warning that the move would prolong the suffering in the enclave and the leader of the Palestinian Authority issuing a strong condemnation.
content: Criticism of a U.S. veto of a United Nations Security Council resolution for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza grew on Saturday, with rights groups and aid organizations warning that the move would prolong the suffering in the enclave and the leader of the Palestinian Authority issuing a strong condemnation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: 2 Books for Cooks
description: A Laurie Colwin classic and a modern chef’s posthumous memoir.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Our Most Popular Recipes of 2023
description: Among the dishes our readers really love: ricotta pasta alla vodka, vegetarian tamale pie and, fittingly enough, Marry Me chicken.
content: We know — 2023 isn’t over yet. There are still many holiday parties and cookie swaps and family dinners to barrel through. But these recipes have been such major hits with our readers that we figure we’re good to share them now. For that holiday party, how about roasted cauliflower with crispy Parmesan, which works as either a crowd-pleasing veggie side or part of an appetizer spread? For the cookie swap, you’ll want to refer to our 2023 Cookie Week recipes, but any sweet treat would be perfect paired with a bubbly tinto de verano. (Yes, summer is in the drink’s name, but this refreshing mix of red wine and citrus soda is delightful year-round.) And you have several options for that family dinner: white chicken chili (above), shrimp tacos or this perfect eggplant Parmesan that’s already dressed in red and green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim, Edward Wong and Thomas Fuller
title: Pressure Rising on U.S. After Vetoing U.N. Call for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: As fighting surged in the territory, Arab leaders condemned the move as a “mark of shame,” one that will haunt the United States for years.
content: The United States, diplomatically isolated after casting the sole vote against a United Nations resolution calling for a cease-fire in Gaza, came under growing criticism on Saturday by a number of governments, human rights groups and aid organizations that warned of catastrophic consequences for civilians in the war-torn territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Maria Emilia Martin, Creator of Public Radio’s ‘Latino USA,’ Dies at 72
description: As a radio journalist committed to the goal of representing all voices, she fought to tell the stories of Latino communities in the Americas.
content: Maria Emilia Martin, who founded “Latino USA,” which is now the longest-running public radio show in the country covering Latino communities, and who trained and mentored hundreds of journalists in Central and South America, died on Dec. 2 at a hospice facility in Austin, Texas. She was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul, Alan Blinder, Anemona Hartocollis and Maureen Farrell
title: Penn’s Leadership Resigns Amid Controversies Over Antisemitism
description: The president, Elizabeth Magill, and the chairman of the board of trustees, Scott L. Bok, are leaving after intense pressure from donors, politicians and alumni.
content: The president of the University of Pennsylvania, M. Elizabeth Magill, resigned on Saturday, four days after she appeared before Congress and appeared to evade the question of whether students who called for the genocide of Jews should be punished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Political Pun-ditry
description: Zachary David Levy and Jeff Chen’s puzzle somehow makes Washington fun.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Majors Urged Ex-Girlfriend Not to Seek Aid After Head Wound, Jury Hears
description: The actor Jonathan Majors made the request after an incident in London last year, according to previously undisclosed text messages read at his assault trial.
content: The actor Jonathan Majors implored his former girlfriend not to seek medical help after she sustained a head injury in an unspecified incident in London last year, telling her, “I fear you have no perspective of what could happen if you go to the hospital.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Where Did All the Hong Kong Neon Go?
description: A government crackdown on neon signs stems from safety and environmental concerns, but the campaign evokes the fading of the city itself.
content: It was never just about the neon, that Cubist, consumerist razzle-dazzle cantilevered over Hong Kong’s streets announcing pawnbrokers and mooncake bakers, saunas and shark’s fin soup shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: Printed With Company
description: In Queens, The New York Times shares its printing presses with more than two dozen other periodicals.
content: On Wednesday night, Sept. 20, 2023, the next day’s newspapers were thundering through the mammoth Goss Colorliner presses at the 13-acre printing plant of The New York Times in College Point, Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britons Love the N.H.S. Some Will Also Pay to Avoid It.
description: With millions-long lines for routine surgery, it has become more common for patients to pay for procedures. That carries risks for the future of the treasured public system.
content: For David Haselgrove, it was a battle each day to get out of bed, then another struggle to put on his socks. Stairs were often impossible, and the pain made him tetchy and difficult to live with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Biggest Fossil Fuel Proponents Make Their Case at Climate Conference
description: Danielle Smith, the premier of Alberta, and Scott Moe of Saskatchewan made their way to the U.N. climate summit.
content: The idea that fossil fuels have a long-term future in the global economy is one that is anathema to the many environmentalists attending the U.N. climate summit being hosted by the United Arab Emirates. But to two Canadian premiers who are also attending, the idea is gospel, and the conference is an ideal place to mint converts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Max Bearak
title: Azerbaijan Is Expected to Host the U.N. Climate Summit in 2024
description: An agreement ended a monthslong deadlock in which Russia exercised veto power over countries that had criticized its invasion of Ukraine.
content: The next United Nations climate change summit appears set to take place in Azerbaijan, a spokesman for the country said Saturday, resolving a bitter, monthslong political standoff over which nation should host the talks in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Both Israel and Hamas Tell of Failed Attempt to Rescue Hostages in Gaza
description: The two sides made competing claims about deaths and injuries inflicted in the mission on Friday.
content: Israeli troops conducted at least one targeted raid in the Gaza Strip on Friday in a failed attempt to rescue hostages held by Hamas, both sides said, making competing claims about deaths and injuries inflicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Katarina Premfors
title: How Can Buildings Beat the Heat in a Desert City? Blend Ancient and Modern.
description: More architects in the United Arab Emirates, the host of this year’s U.N. climate summit, are moving past glass skyscrapers and focusing on sustainability.
content: Dubai is full of futuristic, glazed skyscrapers. That’s problematic, from a sustainability perspective, in a city where temperatures regularly climb past 100 degrees Fahrenheit for several months each year. Air-conditioning can be so strong in the summer that some people wear jackets and scarves inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Protesters Test the Limits of Repressive Dubai’s Climate Summit
description: The annual U.N. talks have brought the rare spectacle of demonstrations to the United Arab Emirates, the oil producer hosting the conference.
content: A woman dressed as a dugong, a rare marine mammal, beseeched passers-by to end the burning of fossil fuels. Protesters wiped away tears as they recited the names of Palestinians killed by Israel’s bombardment of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Record of the Year
description: It’s year-end list time. What are your favorites from 2023?
content: Three weeks left in the year, but don’t be fooled: December has its own peculiar velocity. Weeks seem to pass more quickly as the month goes on, a downhill sled picking up speed. Depending on your orientation to the holidays, the end of 2023 or time’s passage in general, this could feel exciting or it could be bewildering. Here we go, ready or not! Into the small hours of the year, into the dawn of another one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Hello, I Do Not Work Seven Days a Week
description: Why do employers think freelance equals full time, all the time?
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: In Las Vegas, Biden Speaks the Name He Often Doesn’t
description: The president openly attacked his predecessor, former President Donald J. Trump, deploying direct criticism he has frequently avoided, at an event announcing billions for high-speed rail service.
content: Just a few months ago, President Biden rarely said the name of his likely opponent in the 2024 presidential election — former President Donald J. Trump — instead invoking other Republicans as proxies during public events or, on occasion, referring simply to “the former guy.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Albums That Defined 2023? Let’s Discuss.
description: Our critics debate their year-end lists (and agree on SZA, Olivia Rodrigo and 100 gecs!) in a wrap-up of the year in LPs.
content: The albums that made The New York Times pop music critics’ year-end lists cover a wide range of music: hip-hop, industrial rock, amapiano, country, pop-punk, R&B, corridos tumbados. Hyper-polished and spare; chaotic and highly composed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
title: Fears of a NATO Withdrawal Rise as Trump Seeks a Return to Power
description: Current and former European diplomats said there was growing concern a second Trump presidency could mean an American retreat from the continent and a gutting of NATO.
content: For 74 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been America’s most important military alliance. Presidents of both parties have seen NATO as a force multiplier enhancing the influence of the United States by uniting countries on both sides of the Atlantic in a vow to defend one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Schachar
title: Overlooked No More: Ada Blackjack, Survivor of a Harrowing Arctic Expedition
description: She learned to fend for herself during a venture to Wrangel Island. By the time a rescue ship arrived, she was the last crew member standing.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: In Iowa, Nikki Haley Looks Beyond Her Rivals’ Attacks
description: In her first campaign stop since Wednesday’s heated Republican debate, Ms. Haley suggested that fierce criticism from her opponents continued to not be worth her time.
content: In her first campaign stop since Wednesday’s contentious Republican debate, Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador and former governor of South Carolina, largely ignored the many attacks that her fellow candidates, aware of her rise in the polls, had lobbed at her. What she did discuss suggested she continued to feel that the criticism wasn’t, as she said on Wednesday night, “worth my time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How a Playwright and Novelist Spends His Sundays
description: Vichet Chum, a Cambodian American playwright, often focuses his work on Khmer identity and queerness. His Sundays are spent with fellow artists and his dog, Lucy.
content: Vichet Chum, a Cambodian American playwright, spent much of the fall promoting his debut novel for young adults, “Kween.” That was a horizons-expanding experience for Mr. Chum, 38, who describes his plays as “very adult.” His plays, like the book, are often centered on Khmer identity and queerness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Dr. John A. Talbott, Champion of Care for the Mentally Ill, Dies at 88
description: A psychiatrist and a prolific author, he criticized what he referred to as a “nonsystem” that left vulnerable people on the streets to fend for themselves.
content: Dr. John A. Talbott, a psychiatrist who championed the care of vulnerable populations of the mentally ill, especially the homeless — many of whom were left to fend for themselves in the nation’s streets, libraries, bus terminals and jails after mass closures of state mental hospitals — died on Nov. 29 at his home in Baltimore. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Emily Rhyne
title: Ghosts on the Glacier
description: Decades after the unexplained deaths of two American climbers in Argentina, a camera belonging to one of them was found in the snow. The film held astonishing images, but the mystery endures.
content: Decades after the unexplained deaths of two American climbers in Argentina, a camera belonging to one of them was found in the snow. The film held astonishing images, but the mystery endures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt, Aatish Bhatia, Francesca Paris and Rumsey Taylor
title: What’s the Best ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Strategy? Play and Find Out.
description: Play a simplified version of the bonus round, then read on for strategy advice, whether you’re a future contestant or just watching at home.
content: Play a simplified version of the bonus round, then read on for strategy advice, whether you’re a future contestant or just watching at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: You Be the Banker: Would You Close This Bartender’s Account?
description: Here’s what bank security employees might be thinking when deciding whether to shut down a customer account after detecting unusual activity.
content: Here’s what bank security employees might be thinking when deciding whether to shut down a customer account after detecting unusual activity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, December 10, 2023
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?
content: Can you sort 8 historical events?
source.name: The New York Times
